replies.bodyText:
It's just making sure the type of the artifact is always properties. If we go with this approach then BootstrapConstants.PLATFORM_PROPERTIES_ARTIFACT_ID_SUFFIX is becoming a reserved suffix requiring artifacts with this suffix to be of properties type. Because that's what we are looking for. OTOH, we could support other formats too.
You have a point. The reason I did it this way was I didn't add the type of the artifact to the BOM, so it appeared here as a jar, so I thought that could be a typical "mistake" and decided to not require <type>properties</type> in the BOM.

timeline.bodyText:
Since these would be default values, they should have a low ordinal.  The constant DEFAULT_ORDINAL is the default ordinal for config sources, not the ordinal for default config sources, in case that was a point of confusion.  Using the default ordinal means that the defaults may take precedence over some explicitly configured values.
Our default value configuration source is using an ordinal of Integer.MIN_VALUE (see io.quarkus.deployment.configuration.DefaultValuesConfigurationSource), so I think it would be appropriate to use, say, Integer.MIN_VALUE + 1000 or something along those lines.
timeline.author: dmlloyd

timeline.bodyText: I was thinking about this further and I had a concern.  The platform configuration source most likely should be based on a io.smallrye.config.KeyMapBackedConfigSource which can have a default value that matches a pattern.  This would allow configuration keys which have map key components to have a default value.
timeline.author: dmlloyd

replies.bodyText: Should I be looking into creating values as nesed KeyMaps?
replies.author: aloubyansky

replies.bodyText:
Right, IIRC it would look something like this to add some key under quarkus.foo.bar.*.baz:
keyMap.findOrCreate("quarkus", "foo", "bar").getOrCreateAny().findOrCreate("baz").putRootValue("the-default-value");
replies.author: dmlloyd

replies.bodyText: Is there some kind of utility for that I should be splitting the key "manually"?
replies.author: aloubyansky

replies.bodyText: There's no canonical input format for key patterns (just the conventional style I used above), so there isn't really an answer to that question.  Ideally we could avoid having any kind of flat map (e.g. properties) as an input source.  Something hierarchical (e.g. YAML) could sidestep the problem.  Otherwise, yes, you'll have to devise an unambiguous syntax and a splitter for that syntax.
replies.author: dmlloyd
